Award.AbstractNarration:
Through this award, the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program is funding Professor Catalina Achim at Carnegie Mellon University to carry out studies of metal-containing, ligand-modified nucleic acid structures, with a particular emphasis on peptide nucleic acid (PNA) triplexes. Metal complexes with coordination number 3 to 6 will be incorporated in the PNA triplexes by substitution of a triplet of nucleobases with two or three mono-, bi-, or tri-dentate ligands. The ligand modification of PNA triplexes will be used to integrate metal ions with larger DNA nanostructures, which have an extensive range of topologies and geometries. This method may lead in the future to complex inorganic nucleic acid structures with interesting magnetic and electronic properties.

Current technological advances and needs require the manufacturing of materials that have morphological features close to the size of molecules and atoms. A candidate for building blocks for such materials are nucleic acids, of which DNA is an example, because the information needed to assemble two- and three dimensional structures from nucleic acids can be encoded in their sequence just as the genetic information is encoded. Research in Professor Achim's group takes advantage of these properties of nucleic acids and makes use of chemical synthesis and spectroscopy methods to create and characterize metal-containing, nucleic acid nanostructures. The graduate and undergraduate students who conduct the research acquire knowledge and skills of chemistry, biology and physics. The results of the proposed research are integrated in a course on Functional Nanodevices Based on Nucleic Acids for graduate and undergraduate students. Professor Achim is the Director of DNAZone, the outreach program of the Center for Nucleic Acids Science and Technology at Carnegie Mellon. She and her students participate in the development and delivery of the outreach activities of DNAZone, which are intended to improve the engagement, attitudes and beliefs of 4th-12th grade students towards STEM careers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our research goal led to the synthesis and characterization of metal-containing, nano-size structures based on peptide nucleic acids (PNA) that have potential nanotechnology applications. We have expanded the scope of nucleic acid scaffolds for transition metal complexes that act as alternative base pairs to include peptide nucleic acid triplexes. 

Our research showed that six-coordinate metal binding sites can be created at specific positions in PNA triplexes by substituting a triplet of nucleobases with three bidentate ligands.  PNA duplexes and triplexes that contain transition metal complexes as alternative base pair and triplets, respectively, can be bridged by transition metal complexes with terminal ligands situated in the same duplexes and triplexes.  The relative orientation of the PNA duplexes bridged by transition metal complexes is influenced by the geometry of the metal complex bridge.

A new mini course on Communication Issues in Scientific Research has been developed and taught to senior undergraduate students and graduate students.  In the course, the students learn how to develop research projects that are concomitantly ambitious and commensurate with available resources and that contain testable hypotheses. They also learn principles for writing clear and persuasive proposals based on the developed research plans.  

The NSF funding also supported the involvement in the outreach of the faculty and students who participated in the research. The PI has been the director of DNAZone, the STEM outreach program of the Center for Nucleic Acids Science and technology at CMU.  DNAZone volunteers work to improve the engagement, attitudes, and beliefs towards the science of K-12 students in Allegheny County through three distinct outreach endeavors. DNAZone volunteers lead hands-on scientific demonstrations at university, community, or other local events. Also, DNAZone provides professional development to Pittsburgh-area middle and high school science teachers. Finally, DNAZone loans free resources such as materials and experiment lesson plans to 4th-12th-grade science teachers through its Classroom Kit Lending Library.  

The Classroom Kit Lending Library has been created because education research shows that active learning, which takes place when students are engaged in hands-on experiments, is very effective.  The purpose of the Library is to give teachers the resources necessary to teach STEM using experiments that students can do in the classrooms.  Each Kit contains teaching materials for activities and demonstrations that the teachers can use in Biology, Chemistry or Physics classes. The learning objectives of each Kit fulfill the Science Standards of the Pennsylvania Department of Education.  Teachers are provided also with the Curriculum Insertion Points for each activity and with links to other resources they can use in the classroom in relation to the topic that the Kit illustrates.
